where E, S, and C are the three vulnerability assessment components of exposure, sensitivity, and coping, respectively. VA 1 and VM 1 are vulnerability composite indicators by additive and multiplicative forms, respectively. The equal weighting factors can usually be assumed for each component as used in some previous studies
12– 17 . Note that in the functional relationship between attribute components and the vulnerability indicator, higher coping measures contributing to less vulnerable situations can decrease the overall vulnerability value, while higher scores of exposure and sensitivity contribute to the increasing composite indicator
3 . Thus, the coping score with a negative elasticity is employed as a subtrahend in Eq. ( 3) and a divisor in Eq. ( 4).
